Technical Assistance Report
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Project Number: 44176 
Research and Development Technical Assistance (RDTA) 
June 2010 
 
 
 
 
Selected Evaluation Studies for 2010, Phase 1

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
      ADB    –  Asian Development Bank 
      ADF    –  Asian Development Fund 
      DMC    –  developing member country 
      IED    –  Independent Evaluation Department 
SES    –  special evaluation study 
      TA    –  technical assistance 
       
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Research  and  development  technical  assistance 
(RDTA) 
Targeting Classification  –  General intervention 
Sector  –  Multisector 
Themes  –  Economic  growth,  social  development,  private 
sector development  
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Director General   H. S. Rao, Independent Evaluation Department (IED) 
Directors    R. B. Adhikari, Independent Evaluation Division 1, IED 
                     Hemamala Hettige, Independent Evaluation Division 2, IED 
 
Team leader    V.B. Tulasidhar, Advisor, IED 
Team members  A. Abello, Associate Evaluation Coordinator, IED  
      J. Tubadeza, Senior Evaluation Officer, IED 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Independent Evaluation Department (IED)1 of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
develops  its  3-year  evaluation  program  in  consultation  with  ADB’s  Board  of  Directors 
Development  Effectiveness  Committee,  Management,  and  operations  departments.  The 
proposed research and development technical assistance (TA) will be used to finance the 
following activities in IED's 2010 work program:2 (i) updating the evaluation findings on Asian 
Development Fund (ADF) VIII and ADF IX, and assessing the implementation progress of ADF 
X; (ii) assessing the post-project completion sustainability of ADB-funded projects in a number 
of critical sectors; (iii) evaluating the impact of ADB support to commercialization of agriculture 
and agri-business projects on inclusive growth and poverty reduction; (iv) validating regional 
cooperation partnership strategy and country partnership strategy final reviews; (v) undertaking 
sector and thematic evaluations; and (vi) disseminating evaluation knowledge products. Such 
multicountry and multisector evaluation activities—which are  geared to improve development 
effectiveness in developing member countries (DMCs)—have benefited from the use of ADB TA 
resources, which are more responsive in providing the needed inputs. This is first of the two TAs 
planned for 2010.3 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  ADB  Strategy  2020's4  results  framework  and  its  annual  review5  have  brought 
development effectiveness to the core of ADB operations. This TA helps IED provide evaluative 
feedback  on  ADB's  operational  effectiveness  in  three  important  areas:  (i)  the  use  of 
concessional ADF resources; (ii) post-completion sustainability of ADB-funded projects in a 
number of sectors and regions; and (iii) the effectiveness of assistance for commercializing the 
agriculture sector, which is an important activity to achieve inclusive development by creating 
productive employment in rural areas, where poverty in most ADB DMCs is concentrated.  
 
A.  Evaluation of Asian Development Fund Operations 
 
3.  IED has evaluated ADF operations three times. The first evaluation6 covered operations 
from ADF I to ADF V. The second evaluation7 covered operations during the ADF VI and ADF 
VII periods, and the third8 (carried out in 2007), covered the ADF VIII and IX periods. The third 
review was a real-time evaluation of ongoing operations based on a desk review of portfolio 
performance, and was based on limited data: only 22 out of 245 projects funded by ADF VIII 
and ADF IX were complete, and of these just eight had been self-evaluated by the regional 
departments in their project completion reports (PCRs). IED had done no project performance 
evaluation  reports  (PPERs)  for  projects  funded  by  ADF  VIII  at  the  time  of  the  third  ADF 
                                                 
1  IED was named the Operations Evaluation Department, or OED, until December 2008. 
2  The Board approved IED's 2010–2012 work program in December 2009. The 2010 work program includes 41 
evaluation studies and 40 project and program completion report validations. Subsequent to the approval of the 
program, IED included evaluations of ADF operations and the ADB Institute in its 2010 work program in response 
to requests from ADB Strategy and Planning Department and Development Effectiveness Committee.  The IED 
Work Program is available at http://www.adb.org/evaluation/about/workprograms.asp 
3  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 18 May 2010.  
4  ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020: The Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank, 2008–2020. 
Manila. 
5  ADB's development effectiveness is reviewed annually. For instance, see ADB. 2009. Development Effectiveness 
Review. Manila. http://www.adb.org/Documents/Reports/Development-Effectiveness-Review/2009/default.asp 
6  ADB. 2001. A Review of the Asian Development Fund I-V Operations. Manila 
7  ADB. 2003. Special Evaluation Study of the Asian Development Fund VI−VII Operations. Manila. 
8  ADB. 2007. Evaluation of the Asian Development Fund VIII and IX Operations. Manila.

2 
evaluation. It is expected that a large number of the projects financed by ADF VIII and several 
ADF IX projects will be complete by early 2010, thereby providing the operational data needed 
to make a firmer assessment of development effectiveness. The proposed evaluation is the 
fourth to assess the development effectiveness of ADF-funded operations. The evaluation will 
help (i) improve selection, preparation, and implementation of future ADF-funded projects to 
enhance their development impact; and (ii) inform preparation of ADF XI. 
 
4.  ADB's Strategy 2020 mandates that ADF operations contribute to: (i) growth with equity; 
(ii) environmental sustainability of development; and (iii) promotion of national public goods in 
combination  with  cross-border,  sub-regional,  and  global  public  goods.  Using  this  strategic 
framework as a backdrop, the evaluation will seek to answer the following key questions:  
(i)  Has ADB fulfilled its obligations and the commitments made during the ADF VIII, 
IX and X replenishment discussions?  
(ii)  Has  ADB  reoriented  its  overall  strategy  and  operational  priorities  to  support 
poverty  reduction,  while  continuing  efforts  to  stimulate  broad-based  and 
sustainable economic growth?  
(iii)  To  what  extent  has  debt  sustainability  been  taken  into  account  in  ADF 
operations, and how effective has the ADF grant mechanism been compared to 
ADF  lending  and  ordinary  capital  resources  loans  in  delivering  development 
results?  
B.  Post-Completion Sustainability of ADB-Funded Projects 
 
5.   Post-evaluation reports rate approximately a third of ADB projects “not likely to be 
sustainable”. According to IED guidelines, a project could be considered sustainable if the 
human,  institutional,  financial  and  natural  resources  are  likely  to  be  sufficient,  with  high 
probability, to maintain the project outcomes over its economic lifetime; and any imminent risks 
to project sustainability could be managed. Project sustainability is influenced by a number of 
factors. They include: (i) economic factors encompassing market demand and efficiency of 
investments; (ii) project management, project financing, and cost recovery; (iii) project design 
and its technical efficiency; (iv) use of resources and impact on the environment; (v) legal and 
regulatory environment; (vi) institutional development and managerial capacity; and (vii) the 
government's political commitment to the project and the associated policy and institutional 
arrangements, including reforms. The importance of these factors and the extent and intensity 
of their impact on project sustainability vary across sectors and regions. Assessing the risks and 
potential impacts of these factors on project sustainability, in a particular sector at a particular 
place and time, is an important task at project appraisal. 
 
6.  ADB's post-project and post-program evaluation guidelines require a careful assessment 
of sustainability during a project or program’s economic lifetime.9 The following questions are 
critical to sustainability:  
(i)  Would the benefits from ADB-funded projects continue after project completion 
and cessation of ADB funding?  
(ii)  What determines the sustainability of ADB-funded projects?  
(iii)  What is required to mitigate the risks to sustainability identified at appraisal? 
Would the mitigation measures themselves be feasible and sustainable?  
                                                 
9  ADB. 2006. Guidelines for Preparing Performance Evaluation Reports for Public Sector Operations. Manila.

3 
(iv)  What strategic approach should ADB take to ensure a project’s post-completion 
sustainability?  
C.  Effectiveness of Support to Agribusiness to Promote Value Chains for Inclusive 
Development. 
 
7.  In spite of the considerable progress in poverty alleviation in Asia, rural poverty remains 
high, and over three quarters of the Asian poor reside in rural areas. Improving the productivity 
of agriculture sector is critical for providing sustainable employment to the rural poor to alleviate 
poverty. Rapid economic progress and urbanization provides growth opportunities for higher 
value-added,  labor  intensive  farm-based  activities  in  agro-processing,  dairy  products, 
horticulture, and livestock products. This requires investments in rural infrastructure to provide 
access to water, transport, and storage facilities, as well as areas in which the private sector 
could play an important role, such as agricultural extension services, agro-processing, and farm 
logistics. A conducive legal, policy, and institutional environment to commercialize farm activities 
will stimulate private enterprise and investment. The study will evaluate: (i)  comprehensiveness 
of  support  for  commercial  agriculture  and  agribusiness  to  promote  socially  inclusive  and 
sustainable economic development, (ii) policy and institutional framework for respective roles of 
public vis-a-vis private sector in agribusiness development, and (iii) extent of integration of 
smallholder producers and micro-enterprises with value chain market including supermarkets. 
The study will assess the inclusiveness of value chain development and the benefits accrued to 
poorer farmers, women and marginal groups.  
 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The impact of the TA is improved development effectiveness of ADB operations and 
policies  through  learning  from  evaluation  findings.  The  outcome  of  the  TA  is  improved  (i) 
formulation and implementation of country and sector strategies, and ADB policies; and (ii) 
designs  of  projects  and  programs  based  on  IED  evaluation  findings,  lessons,  and 
recommendations.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
9.  The TA will support special evaluation studies (SESs) to assess: (i) ADF operations, (ii) 
the sustainability of ADB projects and programs, and (iii) the effectiveness of ADB assistance 
for agro-business and commercialization of agriculture. The TA will also provide support to (i) 
validation of regional cooperation partnership strategy and country partnership strategy final 
reviews; (ii) sector and thematic evaluations; and (ii) dissemination of evaluation knowledge 
products. The scope, methodology, resource requirements, consultants' terms of reference, and 
knowledge  dissemination  plan  of  each  of  the  evaluations  are  outlined  in  their  respective 
evaluation approach papers.

4 
10.   Special evaluation study of the Asian Development Fund operations. The SES will 
evaluate ADF-funded projects, and related business processes and policies.10 To address the 
issues and questions raised in paras. 3 and 4 (above), the SES will rely on the following 
approach and activities: (i) analyze the ADF portfolio in detail to (a) study the composition of 
ADF allocations, and (b) assess the support for regional cooperation and integration, poverty 
alleviation, Millennium Development Goals, and climate change; (ii) do meta-evaluation and 
synthesis of key findings regarding the development effectiveness of ADF operations from 
evaluation  reports;  (iii)  review  and  synthesize  studies  and  reports  on  ADB  reforms, 
organizational effectiveness and development effectiveness; (iv) review and synthesize existing 
documents assessing ADF operations including the relevant documents and reports; (v) analyze 
the findings of the ongoing SESs;11 (vi) conduct field-level consultations in the top five ADF 
recipient countries; (vii) interview ADB project officers involved in ADF operations; and (viii) 
discuss initial study findings at a workshop with key DMC representatives and development 
partners.  
 
11.  Special evaluation study of post-completion sustainability of ADB projects. The 
aim of this SES is to assess the sustainability of ADB-funded projects and programs, keeping in 
mind the questions and issues discussed in paras. 5 and 6 (above). The SES will cover public 
sector project and program loans and their associated TA projects. The study will cover the 
following  subsectors,  which  receive  significant  ADB  assistance:  (i)  pre-primary  and  basic 
education; (ii) conventional energy, energy sector development, and large hydropower; (iii) road 
transport; (iv) water supply and sanitation; (v) finance sector development; and (vi) small and 
medium-sized enterprise development. 
 
12.  In particular, the study will (i) assess, based on all evaluation ratings since 2001, the 
temporal,  sectoral,  modality,  and  country  patterns  of  sustainability  ratings;  (ii)  study  the 
relationship between effectiveness and/or efficiency and sustainability; (iii) analyze the reasons 
for high and low sustainability ratings; (iv) review literature to help identify the critical success 
factors for sustainability; (v) make case studies in four selected sectors to examine how ADB 
identified and mitigated sustainability risks at each stage of the project cycle; (vi) examine the 
sustainability  of  projects  chosen  for  case  studies  and  their  post-completion  monitoring  by 
executing  agencies;    (vii)  compare  ADB's  policies  for  promoting  project  and  program 
sustainability with those of other multilateral development banks; and (viii) based on the above, 
draw  inferences  regarding  ADB's  policy  and/or  approach  to  sustainability  and  make 
recommendations for improvement.  
 
13.  Study  on  support  to  agribusiness  to  promote  value  chains  for  inclusive 
development. The evaluation will cover all stages in the value chain—from farm production and 
post production systems including processing and marketing, and their interdependencies. The 
study will focus on high value farm and agribusiness products produced by micro, small and 
medium  enterprises  and/or  households  located  mainly  in  rural  areas.  The  study  will  be 
conducted in two stages. The first stage will assess ADB's assistance in promoting commercial 
agriculture in DMCs based on a review of completed evaluation reports. The second stage will 
assess  the  performance,  relevance,  effectiveness  of  the  ongoing  and  completed  projects 
approved between 2001 and 2009 in developing agribusiness and value chain. The study will 
                                                 
10  To enable the evaluation to start immediately, a minor change in scope under ADB. 2009. Selected Evaluation 
Studies for 2009, Phase 2. Manila:  was approved on 16 April 2010 to fund the study's initial consulting 
requirements. The balance required to complete the evaluation will be funded through the proposed TA. 
11  On (i) weakly performing countries, (ii) gender and development, (iii) multisector, (iv) water policy, (v) project 
sustainability, and (vi) Lao People's Democratic Republic country and sector level evaluations.

5 
examine: (i) vertical integration from farm production and processing to logistic support, and to 
marketing;  (ii)  coordination  and  linkages  between  agriculture,  logistic  systems,    and  other 
sectors; (iii) cost-effectiveness in out-reach to a large number of stakeholder and participants; 
(iv) stakeholder commitment; and (v) competitiveness and access to domestic and international 
markets.  
  
14.  Validation of regional cooperation partnership strategy and country partnership 
strategy final reviews. Selectively, IED will validate the final reviews to feed into the respective 
future regional cooperation and country partnership strategies. 
 
15.  Sector and thematic evaluations. The TA will support selected country and sector, 
and/or thematic assessments needed to feed into high-level evaluation reports included in IED 
work program. 
 
16.  Dissemination  of  evaluation  knowledge  products.  Disseminating  evaluation 
knowledge products at appropriate time, place and in a suitable form is an important objective of 
IED. The TA will provide expert inputs required to support IED staff to strengthen dissemination. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
17.  The cost of the TA is estimated at $750,000. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF–IV). The cost estimates and financing plan 
are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
18.  ADB will be the executing agency for the TA. IED will implement the TA and supervise 
the preparation of reports for each evaluation study. Based on experience with similar studies, 
about 18 person-months of international and about 31 person-months of national consulting 
services will be required. The outline terms of reference are in Appendix 3. Detailed terms of 
reference will be given in the evaluation approach papers before action is taken to engage 
consultants. ADB will engage consultants on an individual basis in accordance with ADB's 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). Disbursements 
under the TA will be  made in accordance with ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement 
Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). The TA is estimated to start in June 2010 and 
be completed in December 2011. Implementation arrangements will be flexible enough to allow 
changes should IED’s work program be altered including, as needed, responding to priorities 
under Strategy 2020 and ADF X. ADB will obtain a no-objection from the DMC government prior 
to commencing any activity financed under this TA in the territory of the DMC concerned. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 on a grant basis for 
Selected Evaluation Studies for 2010, Phase 1, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Appendix 3  9 
SUMMARY TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Special evaluation study of the Asian Development Fund operations. The study will 
update the Asian Development Fund (ADF) VIII and IX operations evaluation and examine 
progress on ADF X. The proposed technical assistance (TA) will fund the study's consulting 
requirements comprising about 4 person-months of international consulting services and 12 
person-months of national consulting services (in-country consultants for case studies). The 
international  consultant  will  (i)  analyze  and  compare  the  portfolio  and  pipeline  project 
performance and success rates of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) operations supported by 
ADF VIII, IX, and X; and ordinary capital resources for the corresponding periods based on 
project portfolio and performance data collected by the ADB. This task will require updating the 
special evaluation study on ADF VIII and IX operations on key operational and strategic areas; 
(ii) evaluate the performance of ADF VIII, IX, and X grants, loans, and TA operations against the 
stated objectives on the basis of relevance, effectiveness, efficiency, sustainability, and likely 
impact; (iii) undertake an analysis of ADF-type funds in other multilateral agencies; (iv) assist 
with  refining  study  methodology  and  analysis;  (v)  draft  thematic  chapters  and  associated 
supplementary  appendixes;    and  (vi)  if  required,  participate  in  the  independent  evaluation 
mission  (IEM)  to  selected  ADF  countries  to  discuss  with  the  executing  and  implementing 
agencies, development partners, civil society organizations, and ADB resident missions. 
 
2.  The five national consultants in the case study countries will (i) review project documents 
and update data and information and update profiles of five case study projects covered in the 
special evaluation study on ADF VIII and IX operations with additional information, including a 
review of evaluation performance criteria; (ii) collect up-to-date information on five additional 
ADF operations funded under ADF IX and X, and assess their performance; (iii) undertake field 
visits to selected project sites and prepare project evaluation profiles based on desk review and 
field visits and project data analysis; and (iv) assist the IEM during country visits. 
 
3.  Special evaluation study on post-completion sustainability of ADB projects. The 
study will be supported by two international consultants (4 person-months): (i) an evaluation 
specialist (sustainability) for 2.5 person-months, and (ii) a finance and small and medium-sized 
enterprises evaluation specialist for 1.5 person-months. The evaluation specialist (sustainability) 
will assist with refining the evaluation's methodologies, participate in the case studies and 
review of ADB's policies, and take the lead role in drawing together the work of the team 
members into a draft report. The evaluation specialist (finance and small and medium-sized 
enterprises) will focus on undertaking the case studies in the finance and trade sectors by 
reviewing  the  evaluation's  proposed  methodology  for  the  case  studies;  applying  the 
methodology developed for the evaluation in undertaking the case studies in the finance and 
trade sectors; conducting consultations with various stakeholders as required; participating in 
country missions and drafting case studies in the finance and trade sectors. 
 
4.  Five national consultants (about 5 person-months of total inputs) will also be employed 
to support the case study missions in the selected developing member countries. The five 
evaluation  officers  will  (i)  review  background  reports  and  other  materials  to  develop  an 
understanding of the relevant ADB loans and TAs for their country; (ii) undertake field visits as 
required; (iii) assess the current status of the selected ADB projects for their compliance with 
major covenants and their current financial, economic, technical, and institutional sustainability; 
and (iv) assist the IEM during country visits.  
 
5.  Study  on  support  to  agribusiness  to  promote  value  chains  for  inclusive 
development. The study will require services of (i) an international consultant for 2 person-

10  Appendix 3 
months and selected country-based national consultants for 4 person-months. The international 
consultant  will  (i)  undertake  a  meta-evaluation  study  of  agriculture  commercialization  and 
agribusiness  with  focus  on  value  chain  development;  (ii)  review  pertinent  ADB  plans  and 
policies in this area, as applicable; (iii) undertake a careful assessment of success factors or 
lack thereof from ADB's completed and ongoing projects; (iv) identify key lessons and issues 
and formulate recommendations for future ADB assistance for commercialization of agriculture 
in the context of Strategy 2020; and (v) conduct field visits to all selected countries.  
 
6.  The four national consultants will (i) provide logistical support for the selected country 
case studies, (ii) review national policies and support provided by ADB and the governments on 
agribusiness development, and (iii) prepare country specific inputs to the draft study. 
 
7.  Regional cooperation partnership strategy and country partnership strategy final 
review validations reports. The preparation of regional cooperation partnership strategy and 
country partnership strategy final review validations will require the services of an international 
evaluation specialist for about 3 person-months and national consultants for about 4 person-
months. The international consultant would assist in (i) assessing the quality of about four 
regional cooperation partnership strategy and country partnership strategy final reviews based 
on the established criteria; and (ii) preparing validation reports in terms of identifying areas 
where the draft can be improved with respect to validity of conclusions, internal consistency, 
and appropriateness of recommendations. The national consultants will undertake field visits to 
selected project sites and assist the IEM during country visits. 
 
8.  Sector and thematic evaluations. Depending on country and sector requirements, 
sector and/or thematic assessments will be undertaken to feed into the main country assistance 
program evaluation reports. Sector assistance program evaluations assess ADB's strategy, 
policy dialogue, ongoing and completed projects and technical assistance, and performance 
within a given sector in one country. Their preparation will require the services of sector and/or 
theme  specialists  (both  international  and  national).  The  international  consultants  (about  5 
person-months of total inputs) are expected to (i) update reviews of ADB-financed assistance 
programs and assess their relevance, effectiveness, sustainability, and impact to and on the 
strategic sector objectives; (ii) undertake key informant interviews and conduct stakeholder 
surveys on the outcome and impact of ADB assistance, and discuss sector development issues 
and concerns with executing agencies and other government and nongovernment entities, as 
appropriate; and (iii) help assess the validity of ADB’s sector development strategies in their 
respective study country. 
 
9.  With  attention  to  country  and  sector  requirements,  national  sector  and/or  theme 
specialists (6 person-months of total inputs) with previous exposure to sector development 
issues in the study country will be recruited to (i) present an overview of the relevance and 
implementation of ADB sector strategies; (ii) assess and rate the achievement of project and 
program objectives, and the delivery of core sectors and crosscutting and thematic programs; 
(iii) comment on ADB’s institutional positioning and performance in a sector; (iv) organize and 
facilitate focus group discussions, workshops, and meetings; and (v) identify important issues 
and lessons in a sector’s operations.
